questions.text:
A 58-year-old man reports hearing loss in both ears. He describes increased difficulty hearing conversations during the past 2 months, particularly in noisy environments, and has had to increase the volume of his television to hear it. In addition, he has noticed a constant ringing in both ears, which he describes as “a minor annoyance” that does not wake him at night. He has no chronic medical conditions and takes no medications regularly.
Gross evaluation of his hearing reveals reduced perception of whispered voice bilaterally. On Weber testing, he reports lack of lateralization of sound to either ear. The rest of his ear, nose, and throat examination is normal, as are his cardiac and neurologic examinations.
Which one of the following investigations, if any, is most appropriate to evaluate this patient’s tinnitus?

choices.text: Laboratory testing, including thyroid studies and measurement of vitamin B levels
CT angiography of the head and neck
Comprehensive audiologic evaluation
MRI of the head and auditory canal
No further evaluation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laboratory testing is not routinely indicated in the evaluation of tinnitus.

B) INCORRECT:

Tinnitus with more-worrisome features would require urgent testing: Tinnitus that is pulsatile should be evaluated with CT angiography of the head and neck to assess for an underlying vascular process.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s bilateral tinnitus is most consistent with primary, benign tinnitus. Relatively acute, primary tinnitus that is not bothersome to the patient does not typically require further workup. However, this patient has an associated bilateral reduction in hearing, making a comprehensive audiologic examination the most appropriate evaluation.

Tinnitus with more-worrisome features would require urgent testing:

• Tinnitus that is unilateral or that is associated with asymmetric hearing loss or focal neurologic abnormalities should be evaluated with MRI of the head and auditory canal with and without contrast.
• Tinnitus that is pulsatile should be evaluated with CT angiography of the head and neck to assess for an underlying vascular process.
• Sudden onset of tinnitus and hearing loss (during a period of 72 hours or less) is consistent with a diagnosis of sudden sensorineural hearing loss and requires referral for urgent audiometry; empiric glucocorticoid therapy may also be warranted.

Key learning point: A relatively acute (<6 months), constant, bilateral tinnitus associated with hearing changes — but not accompanied by worrisome features — is best evaluated by a complete audiologic evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Tinnitus with more-worrisome features would require urgent testing: Tinnitus that is unilateral or that is associated with asymmetric hearing loss or focal neurologic abnormalities should be evaluated with MRI of the head and auditory canal with and without contrast.

E) INCORRECT:

Relatively acute, primary tinnitus that is not bothersome to the patient does not typically require further workup. However, this patient has an associated bilateral reduction in hearing, making a comprehensive audiologic examination the most appropriate evaluation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to your clinic reporting hearing loss in both ears. Over the past 2 months, he has had increasing difficulty hearing conversations, especially in noisy environments, and has needed to increase the volume on his television. He also describes constant ringing in both ears, which he finds mildly bothersome but does not disturb his sleep. Gross hearing assessment shows reduced perception of whispered voice bilaterally. On Weber testing, there is no lateralization of sound. The remainder of his ear, nose, and throat examination is normal, as are his cardiac and neurologic examinations. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?

choices.text: Comprehensive audiologic evaluation.
No further evaluation.
CT angiography of the head and neck.
Laboratory testing, including thyroid studies and measurement of vitamin B levels.
MRI of the head and auditory canal.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s bilateral tinnitus is most consistent with primary, benign tinnitus. Relatively acute, primary tinnitus that is not bothersome to the patient does not typically require further workup. However, this patient has an associated bilateral reduction in hearing, making a comprehensive audiologic examination the most appropriate evaluation.

Tinnitus with more worrisome features would require urgent testing:

• Tinnitus that is unilateral or that is associated with asymmetric hearing loss or focal neurologic abnormalities should be evaluated with MRI of the head and auditory canal with and without contrast.
• Tinnitus that is pulsatile should be evaluated with CT angiography of the head and neck to assess for an underlying vascular process.
• Sudden onset of tinnitus and hearing loss (during a period of 72 hours or less) is consistent with a diagnosis of sudden sensorineural hearing loss and requires referral for urgent audiometry; empiric glucocorticoid therapy may also be warranted.

Key learning point: A relatively acute (< 6 months), constant, bilateral tinnitus associated with hearing changes — but not accompanied by worrisome features — is best evaluated by a complete audiologic evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Laboratory testing is not routinely indicated in the evaluation of tinnitus.

E) INCORRECT:

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with new-onset ringing in her left ear that began suddenly yesterday. She describes it as a high-pitched constant tone associated with a sensation of fullness and mild dizziness, but no vertigo, headache, or trauma. She has no history of chronic ear disease. She takes atorvastatin and ibuprofen as needed for headaches. Vital signs are normal. Otoscopic examination shows a clear canal and intact tympanic membrane. Tuning fork tests reveal lateralization to the right ear on Weber and a positive Rinne test (air conduction greater than bone conduction) on the left. Neurologic examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Diagnose Ménière’s disease and recommend sodium restriction and outpatient ENT follow-up
Discontinue ibuprofen for suspected ototoxicity and arrange audiology referral within one week
Order CT of the temporal bone to evaluate for ossicular chain disruption
Prescribe meclizine and arrange routine ENT referral
Arrange urgent ENT consultation and initiate corticosteroid therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ménière’s disease presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo lasting minutes to hours, accompanied by fluctuating, not sudden, hearing loss and tinnitus. This patient’s abrupt, persistent unilateral hearing loss is characteristic of sudden sensorineural hearing loss, which requires urgent corticosteroid therapy and ENT consultation, not outpatient dietary management.

B) INCORRECT:

Although some medications (e.g., aminoglycosides, loop diuretics, platinum-based chemotherapeutics) can cause ototoxicity, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs rarely produce sudden, unilateral hearing loss especially when used occasionally. Sudden sensorineural hearing loss is an otologic emergency; ENT follow up in a week would be inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

CT is appropriate for conductive hearing loss or trauma, not for sudden sensorineural loss. MRI of the internal auditory canal is preferred if a retrocochlear lesion is suspected, but immediate management should not be delayed for imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Meclizine may relieve vertigo but does not address sudden hearing loss. The patient’s mild dizziness does not represent vestibular vertigo; delaying appropriate management risks permanent auditory deficit.

E) CORRECT:

Correct — Sudden-onset unilateral tinnitus and hearing loss without middle ear findings indicate sudden sensorineural hearing loss, an otologic emergency. Prompt corticosteroid therapy (oral or intratympanic) improves recovery if started within 72 hours. The ED physician should urgently involve ENT and rule out central causes with MRI if indicated.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of constant “whooshing” in his right ear. He denies pain, fever, or hearing loss. He reports that the sound is pulsatile, synchronous with his heartbeat, and worsens when he lies flat. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia but takes no anticoagulants. Vital signs are BP, 152/92 mm Hg; P, 82; R, 18; T, 36.9°C (98.4°F). Otoscopic examination reveals a normal tympanic membrane without effusion or erythema. No focal neurologic deficits are present. Which of the following is the most appropriate disposition for this patient?

choices.text: Discharge with reassurance and outpatient audiology referral within 4 weeks
Discharge with a presumptive diagnosis of Ménière’s disease and recommend a low-salt diet and ENT follow-up
Provide intranasal decongestants for presumed Eustachian tube dysfunction and discharge
Schedule outpatient carotid Doppler ultrasound within 7 days to exclude carotid disease
Arrange urgent neuroimaging and vascular evaluation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the absence of red flags for tinnitus, patients can be managed nonurgently, but pulsatile tinnitus raises concern for vascular abnormalities such as arteriovenous malformation or carotid dissection. Deferring evaluation risks missing a serious underlying cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Ménière’s disease presents with episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and nonpulsatile tinnitus due to endolymphatic hydrops. This patient’s pulsatile, heartbeat-synchronous tinnitus without vertigo or hearing changes is inconsistent with Ménière’s. Treating empirically for an inner ear disorder would delay recognition of a possible vascular etiology requiring urgent imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Eustachian tube dysfunction typically causes intermittent ear fullness or crackling, not rhythmic, pulse-synchronous tinnitus. Treating as a benign middle-ear disorder would miss a potential vascular or intracranial etiology requiring urgent imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Although vascular assessment is appropriate, delayed outpatient testing is unsafe. Pulsatile tinnitus requires same-day CT or MR angiography, as vascular causes can progress rapidly. Doppler ultrasound alone may miss intracranial pathology.

E) CORRECT:

Correct — Pulsatile tinnitus synchronous with the heartbeat is a red flag for vascular pathology, including arteriovenous malformation, dural sinus thrombosis, carotid dissection, or vascular tumor. Urgent CT angiography or MR angiography of the head and neck is indicated. Because these conditions can lead to hemorrhage or stroke, the patient should be admitted for further evaluation and monitoring.
